Yes it's been documented at length in Latin America and China. The demographics of Brazil went from 1% Protestant 50 years ago to ~15% Protestant. China is the same way. It's hard finding the exact percentage of them in China because the religion is persecuted so much and people rarely openly profess it. I've seen estimates say the Protestant numbers are anywhere between 10,000,000 and 50,000,000. You can fact check me if you want to with a quick internet search

Because it's the only local teams. They fill the niche that Plymouth Argyle, Sheffield Wednesday, and other smaller soccer teams in England and other nations do. Since there's only 32 NFL teams there's not very many teams, and if you don't live in or near a major city there's nothing to cheer for. They give your town or city pride, it's your town vs another town. Also it's kids and players that you may know personally. Also it's YOUR school or college and you take pride in that. When they win you are personally invested in it. Far more so than when a team of professionals that you have 0 connection to in a big city that's hundreds of miles away wins a game.
Also since there is no promotion/relegation college football is the third/fourth level so it's comparable to League 1 2 in the English soccer pyramid in terms of talent. The rivalries are wayyyy more intense because it is more local. I've seen some high school football rivalries that are way more intense than NFL games because it's two towns vs each other, and not random players from all across the nation like in the NFL
Source: played high school college football

That would be great, and I hope you're right, but I don't think anything will come of it. Like I said to another guy, people have been studying this stuff for decades. If it was all that you were saying it was im positive we would've known it by now.

I don't care about marijuana being used for pain easing. That's fine if that's what people want to do. However I find it infuriating when people twist the truth and say things like "it cures cancer!" It doesn't. Sure there have been a few tests showing it might help along with chemotherapy, maybe, but taking medical marijuana will never cure someone of cancer.

Weed has been around for as long as humans have. Experiments have been done on it ever since modern medicine came of age. There isn't going to be some magical new breakthrough after decades of studying it. We know exactly what is and isn't in it, and exactly what it can and can't do.
The "it's gonna happen either way" is such a stupid argument because you can say the same thing about every single crime ever committed. Should murder be legal because "it's gonna happen either way."

You can find isolated medical papers that claim almost anything. Go to the 50s and you can find butt loads of papers that claim LSD other drugs are cures for all sorts of things. Go back 10 years and you can find papers about links between vaccines and autism. Just because you can find a few "big papers" about stuff (that are most of the time only theorizing, not actually stating facts) doesn't mean it's true. You can find "big papers" right now about the links between cell phones and brain tumors, that doesn't mean it's true.

Have you actually watched Dobbs play QB? He's terrible. Take it from someone who watched every Tennessee game last year. Honestly he's an awful passer and is not a NFL QB at all. He can't consistently throw a 7 yard hitch route (see Soutb Carolina, Vanderbilt, Appalachian state games) The only reason he ever started because he could run and Tennessee's offense was built around a running QB.

Josh Dobbs is not a NFL QB. I don't even understand where that rhetoric is coming from. Anybody that actually watched a lot of Tennessee games last year will tell you that. He can't even throw a 7 yard hitch route. He almost got benched multiple times his senior season. He can't read the entire field, so they cut everything in half for him. He turns the ball over in ridiculous amounts. He has a terrible arm.
The only good thing he can do is run the ball and that doesn't work in the NFL.
